provenance.name: Collection of Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Early history not known; Alexander Macmillan by 1876; William Augustus White; acquired by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach from White's estate in 1927; George C. Smith, Jr., sold from his collection, Parke-Bernet auction, New York, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 103 ($375 to the dealer R. Allan, possibly acting for the vendor's sister Mrs. Artemas Holmes); Dorothy S. Holmes by inheritance; offered from the estate of Dorothy S. Holmes, Sotheby's, 18 Nov. 1976, lot 163 (not sold on an estimate of £3000-4000); agreement to purchase made between the estate of Dorothy S. Holmes and Robert N. Essick in summer 1977 but seriously damaged during transport from Sotheby's New York to Sotheby's Los Angeles; the drawing, now in several separate pieces, acquired by Sotheby's insurance company, late summer 1977; acquired by Essick from the insurance company for $159 in Oct. 1977 and subsequently repaired.

objnote.p: Blake developed this subject and basic composition through a series of eight further drawings, including Butlin 120 recto, 120A recto and verso, 121, 122 recto, 123 recto, 124, and possibly untraced 125, *Christ as the Good Shepherd*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The general theme and subject of this composition were probably influenced by several biblical passages, including Ruth 2:1-17, I Samuel 12:16-19, and Matthew 9:38. Christ stands facing right in the center of the composition with both arms extended, at least the right palm facing out to the right. His right foot is prominent beneath his cloak and gown. He turns his head to the left to look down toward a group of three figures—two adults and one child—who kneel in the lower left corner of the scene. The leftmost figure, who is female and nude above the waist, reaches both arms toward the standing figure while a kneeling child leans against her bent legs. The second adult figure also appears to kneel and rest at least one arm by his(?) side. This figural group may represent a family. In the lower right corner another gowned figure, seen from the back, appears to walk or run right with both arms extended. Many other partial and/or indistinct pencil sketches fill the scene, including the suggestion of another small standing figure (perhaps wearing a gown?) to the left of the rightmost figure in the corner, two figures standing above and behind the kneeling group, and, most prominently, another depiction of the central standing figure immediately to the left of the pen-and-ink version. These figures lightly drawn in pencil may be alternative positions for the more prominent figures outlined in pen and ink. Horizontal lines near the midpoint of the right side of the composition may suggest a horizon line or distant fields.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, with long hair and a beard, stands facing right in the center of the composition with both arms raised at 45 degrees, at least the right palm facing out to the right. His right foot is prominent beneath his gown and elaborate cloak, held with a button or brooch at his right shoulder. He turns his head to the left to look down toward a group of three figures who kneel in the lower left corner of the scene. Pencil lines indicate a slightly different position for the figure's arms. The figure lightly sketched in pencil to the left may be an alternative position for Christ.

A group of three figures—two adults and one child—kneel in supplicating postures in the lower left corner. They may represent a family. Pencil lines indicate slightly different outlines for their bodies or clothing.

Facing right, the leftmost figure in the group of three lower left kneels on her bent right knee and prominent right foot and raises her arms horizontally, perhaps reaching toward the standing figure, at whom she also looks, in a gesture of supplication. She wears drapery around her lower body but her bared breasts are prominent. She may be the mother of the child in front of her.
A child sits or kneels on bent legs facing left and away from the viewer, leaning against the female figure's legs.

A group of three figures—two adults and one child—kneel in the lower left corner. Partially obscured by his companions in front of him, the rightmost figure appears to be male and, like the female figure, draped below the waist but nude above. In a posture of supplication, he kneels facing right and rests his left arm by his side with hand on his knee. He looks up toward the standing male figure. If this group represents a family, he may be the father.

In the lower right corner a gowned figure, drawn in pencil and seen from the back, appears to walk or run right with both arms extended, the right bent at the elbow. This figure has long hair and appears to turn its head to look back and up at the standing male figure. The small stature of this figure in comparison with the others may suggest it is a child. The figure outlined to the left may be an alternative position for this figure.

Several partial and/or indistinct pencil sketches fill the scene, including a second depiction of, or alternative position for, the central standing figure of Christ immediately to the left of the pen and ink version. His left arm is indistinct in this pencil version.

Several partial and/or indistinct pencil sketches fill the scene, including the suggestion of another small standing figure (perhaps wearing a gown?) to the left of the child-like figure in the lower right corner.
Several partial and/or indistinct pencil sketches fill the scene, including the heads and torsos of two figures above the kneeling group at left.
Horizontal lines near the midpoint of the right side of the composition may suggest a horizon line or distant fields.
